slides.title: Welcome to Electromagnetism
slides.content:
# Introduction to Electromagnetism âš¡

Welcome to **Electromagnetism** - the study of electric and magnetic phenomena and their deep connection!

## What you'll learn:
- **Electric Fields & Charges** - The fundamental forces
- **Electric Circuits** - Ohm's Law, resistors, capacitors
- **Magnetism** - Magnetic fields and forces
- **Electromagnetic Induction** - Generating electricity
- **AC/DC Circuits** - Powering our world
- **Electromagnetic Waves** - Light, radio, and beyond

> ğŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** James Clerk Maxwell unified electricity and magnetism in 1865, predicting that light is an electromagnetic wave!

## Why Study Electromagnetism?
- ğŸ’¡ **Powers modern life** - Electricity runs everything
- ğŸ“± **Communication** - Radio, WiFi, cellular networks
- ğŸ¥ **Medical technology** - MRI, X-rays, pacemakers
- ğŸš„ **Transportation** - Electric motors, maglev trains

## The Four Maxwell Equations

All of electromagnetism is summarized in just 4 equations:
1. Gauss's Law (Electric)
2. Gauss's Law (Magnetic)
3. Faraday's Law
4. AmpÃ¨re-Maxwell Law

Let's explore the electromagnetic universe!

## Electric Field Lines

### Rules for Drawing Field Lines:

slides.title: Electric Potential and Voltage
slides.content:
# Electric Potential (Voltage) ğŸ”‹

## Definition

Electric potential is the **potential energy per unit charge** at a point.

```
V = U/q = kQ/r
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| V | Electric potential | Volt (V) |
| U | Potential energy | Joule (J) |
| q | Charge | Coulomb (C) |

## Potential Difference (Voltage)

```
Î”V = V_B - V_A = W/q
```

Voltage is the work done per unit charge to move between two points.

## Relationship: Field and Potential

```
E = -Î”V/Î”x
```

- Field points from high to low potential
- Larger potential difference = Stronger field

## Equipotential Surfaces

- Surfaces where V is constant
- Perpendicular to field lines
- No work done moving along them

## Common Voltages

| Source | Voltage |
|--------|--------|
| AA Battery | 1.5 V |
| Car battery | 12 V |
| Wall outlet (US) | 120 V |
| Wall outlet (Europe) | 230 V |
| High-voltage power line | 500,000 V |
| Static shock | 3,000-10,000 V |

## Energy in Electric Fields

```
U = qV
KE gained = qÎ”V (for accelerated charge)
```

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Voltage is like "electrical pressure" - it pushes charges through circuits!

slides.title: Magnetism Fundamentals
slides.content:
# Magnetism ğŸ§²

## Magnetic Poles

- Every magnet has **North (N)** and **South (S)** poles
- Like poles repel, unlike poles attract
- **No magnetic monopoles** exist (always dipoles)

## Magnetic Field (B)

| Source | Field Pattern |
|--------|---------------|
| Bar magnet | Dipole pattern (N to S) |
| Straight wire | Circular around wire |
| Loop/coil | Similar to bar magnet |
| Solenoid | Uniform inside, dipole outside |

## Right-Hand Rules

### For Current-Carrying Wire:
Thumb = current direction
Curled fingers = field direction

### For Force on Moving Charge:
Fingers = B field direction
Thumb = velocity direction
Palm pushes = Force on + charge

## Magnetic Force on Moving Charge

```
F = qvB sin(Î¸)
```

| Symbol | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| F | Magnetic force |
| q | Charge |
| v | Velocity |
| B | Magnetic field |
| Î¸ | Angle between v and B |

## Key Properties

- Force is **perpendicular** to both v and B
- No force on stationary charges
- No force if moving parallel to field
- Magnetic force does **NO WORK** (changes direction, not speed)

## Earth's Magnetic Field

- Acts like a bar magnet
- Magnetic north â‰  Geographic north
- Protects us from solar wind
- Field strength â‰ˆ 25-65 Î¼T

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Magnetic fields exert forces only on MOVING charges!

slides.title: Electromagnetic Induction
slides.content:
# Electromagnetic Induction âš¡

## Faraday's Discovery (1831)

> *A changing magnetic field produces an electric current!*

## Magnetic Flux

```
Î¦ = B Ã— A Ã— cos(Î¸)
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| Î¦ | Magnetic flux | Weber (Wb) |
| B | Magnetic field | Tesla (T) |
| A | Area | mÂ² |
| Î¸ | Angle between B and normal |

## Faraday's Law

```
EMF = -N Ã— (Î”Î¦/Î”t)
```

Induced voltage = Rate of change of flux Ã— Number of turns

## Ways to Induce EMF

| Method | How it changes Î¦ |
|--------|------------------|
| Move magnet | Changes B through loop |
| Move loop | Changes area in field |
| Rotate loop | Changes Î¸ |
| Change B | Direct flux change |

## Lenz's Law

> *Induced current opposes the change that caused it.*

This is the meaning of the (-) sign - nature resists change!

### Example:
Magnet approaching loop â†’ Induced current creates opposing field â†’ Slows magnet

## Applications

| Device | How it uses induction |
|--------|----------------------|
| Generator | Rotating coil in magnetic field |
| Transformer | Changing current induces voltage |
| Induction cooktop | Induces currents in pot |
| Wireless charging | Induces current in device |
| Metal detector | Detects induced currents |

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Faraday's law is how we generate almost ALL electricity!

# Transformers ğŸ”Œ

Transformers change AC voltage levels using electromagnetic induction.

## Structure

```
    Primary    Iron Core    Secondary
    Coil (Nâ‚)     |||    Coil (Nâ‚‚)

```

## Transformer Equation

```
Vâ‚‚/Vâ‚ = Nâ‚‚/Nâ‚ = Iâ‚/Iâ‚‚
```

| Type | Nâ‚‚ vs Nâ‚ | Voltage | Current |
|------|----------|---------|--------|
| **Step-up** | Nâ‚‚ > Nâ‚ | Increases | Decreases |
| **Step-down** | Nâ‚‚ < Nâ‚ | Decreases | Increases |

## Power Conservation

For ideal transformer:
```
P_in = P_out
Vâ‚Iâ‚ = Vâ‚‚Iâ‚‚
```

(Voltage up â†’ Current down, and vice versa)

## Example

**A transformer has 100 primary turns and 1000 secondary turns. If input is 120V, find output.**

Vâ‚‚ = Vâ‚ Ã— (Nâ‚‚/Nâ‚) = 120 Ã— (1000/100) = **1200 V**

## Why Transformers Are Essential

### Power Transmission:

```
Power plant â†’ Step-up transformer â†’ High voltage transmission â†’ Step-down transformer â†’ Homes
    12 kV          500 kV                        120/240 V
```

### Why high voltage?

Power loss = IÂ²R

Higher voltage = Lower current = MUCH less power loss!

## Real Transformer Losses

| Loss Type | Cause |
|-----------|-------|
| Copper losses | Resistance in windings |
| Eddy currents | Currents in core |
| Hysteresis | Magnetization of core |

Efficiency typically 95-99%!

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Transformers enable efficient long-distance power transmission!
